steps.title: Whisk an egg in a medium mixing bowl.
steps.content: Whisk an egg in a medium mixing bowl.

steps.title: Stir in 1 cup chilled seltzer water.
steps.content: Stir in 1 cup chilled seltzer water. The sparkling water makes for a lighter batter, though you can use tap water or bottled water— the colder, the better.

steps.title: Add the flour and corn starch a bit at a time, stirring minimally.
steps.content: Add the flour and corn starch a bit at a time, stirring minimally. Traditional batter (in Japan) is made by stirring briefly with a couple of chopsticks. It is okay to leave lumps in the batter and is best not to over-stir the batter as doing so tends to toughen the coating. Make the tempura batter just before use. It is best made fresh and not stored for later use.

steps.title: Heat the oil to 350℉ (175℃) in a small, deep saucepan.
steps.content: Heat the oil to 350℉ (175℃) in a small, deep saucepan.

steps.title: Remove the abdomens from the tarantulas.
steps.content: Remove the abdomens from the tarantulas. Sever with a sharp knife, then discard the abdomens. Although some strong-stomached individuals happily consume the abdomens, tarantula abdomens are filled with a dark brown paste which contains the heart, the digestive system, and any eggs that might be developing.

steps.title: Singe off any hairs with a crème brûlée torch or butane cigarette lighter.
steps.content: Singe off any hairs with a crème brûlée torch or butane cigarette lighter. After singeing the hairs, run your fingers over the legs to remove the hair remnants and, at the same time, spread the legs evenly around the spider (as well as you can).

steps.title: Coat one spider at a time in the tempura batter, then drop the spider into the hot oil.
steps.content: Coat one spider at a time in the tempura batter, then drop the spider into the hot oil.

steps.title: Deep-fry each tarantula until the batter coating is lightly browned (about 1 minute), then place on a paper towel to drain.
steps.content: Deep-fry each tarantula until the batter coating is lightly browned (about 1 minute), then place on a paper towel to drain.

steps.title: Cut each spider in half lengthwise, sprinkle with paprika, and serve.
steps.content: Cut each spider in half lengthwise, sprinkle with paprika, and serve.

steps.title: Mix the sugar, MSG (optional), and sea salt in a shallow bowl.
steps.content: Mix the sugar, MSG (optional), and sea salt in a shallow bowl.

steps.title: Remove the abdomen from each spider and discard.
steps.content: Remove the abdomen from each spider and discard.

steps.title: Prepare the tarantulas by singeing the hairs with a flame, rubbing off the hair remnants, then spreading and flattening the legs.
steps.content: Prepare the tarantulas by singeing the hairs with a flame, rubbing off the hair remnants, then spreading and flattening the legs.

steps.title: Bring the cooking oil to temperature in a frying pan.
steps.content: Bring the cooking oil to temperature in a frying pan. The oil should be about 350℉ (175℃) and below the smoke point.

steps.title: Add the crushed garlic and fry until fully fragrant.
steps.content: Add the crushed garlic and fry until fully fragrant.

steps.title: Wet the tarantulas slightly and coat with the sugar/salt/(MSG) mixture.
steps.content: Wet the tarantulas slightly and coat with the sugar/salt/(MSG) mixture.

steps.title: Place the tarantulas in the frying pan and cook on each side about one minute.
steps.content: Place the tarantulas in the frying pan and cook on each side about one minute.

steps.title: Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels.
steps.content: Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels.

steps.title: Cut lengthwise and serve.
steps.content: Cut lengthwise and serve.

steps.title: Remove the abdomen from each spider and discard.
steps.content: Remove the abdomen from each spider and discard. Sever with a sharp knife, then discard the abdomens. Although some individuals happily consume the abdomens, tarantula abdomens are filled with a dark brown paste which contains most of the vital organs, including the digestive/elimination system and eggs which may be in various stages of development.

steps.title: Prepare the tarantulas by singeing the hairs with a flame, rubbing off the hair remnants, then spreading and flattening the legs.
steps.content: Prepare the tarantulas by singeing the hairs with a flame, rubbing off the hair remnants, then spreading and flattening the legs.

steps.title: Place each spider on a skewer and grill for two to three minutes.
steps.content: Place each spider on a skewer and grill for two to three minutes. Cooking time will, obviously, depend upon the size of the tarantula and temperature of the grill or open flame. When you feel that the legs are done, you can opt to remove them and continue to cook the mesothorax for a while.

steps.title: Sprinkle the grilled tarantula with sea salt and freshly ground pepper, then cut lengthwise and serve.
steps.content: Sprinkle the grilled tarantula with sea salt and freshly ground pepper, then cut lengthwise and serve.
